segments.text: 1989 at Portland, Texas in the home of Jack Kumkel concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I'm going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that all right with you?
Yes.
I'm going to ask you first about the biological data, your date and place of birth.
September 2nd, 1933 in Indiana, Pennsylvania.
Okay.
Education?
I have a bachelor's degree from the University of Pittsburgh and a MBA from George Washington University.
Okay.
Brief sketch of your military career before Vietnam?
Being a supply corps officer, I was supply officer of the destroyer.
right out of college.
And from there I ran a commissary store in Greencoe Springs, Florida.
From there I was supply officer in a facility in Antigua in the West Indies.
From there I was Navy exchange officer in Washington, D.C. And from there I went to Vietnam.
Your date and
place of tour in Vietnam?
I got there right during the Tet Offensive, which was in 1969, and that was in February of 69, and I left in February of 70.
And where was that?
I went into consulate air base when I first went into Vietnam and I was the supply officer of the Navy facility at Cam Nong Bay.
Your rank?
I was lieutenant commander.
The type of service or job description?
I was the senior supply corps officer for the Navy in 3 Corps.
Vietnam was divided into three areas, and I was the senior supply corps officer in 3 Corps during the time that I was there.
How you felt when you found out you were going to Vietnam?
I volunteered for Vietnam.
Description of the place you were first assigned to?
Initially, I went into Saigon, and this was during the Tet Offensive.
And I spent my first two weeks there in indoctrination because the
funding for Cam Ranh Bay from out of Saigon.
And prior to going up there, I spent two weeks with a Captain Hine there when he picked me up at the airport from Tan Samu.
And I remember going in to Saigon from Tan Samu to the air base where he even, he broke out his .45 and laid it on the window as we were going through some areas of South Vietnam.
And the whole two weeks that I was in Saigon, every night the sky was lit up, the bed shook all day and all night from the bombing around Saigon.
So it was a rather interesting period and one of a lot of activities at the time.
And how much contact did you have with the Vietnamese people, and how did they react to you?
Oh, I loved the Vietnamese people.
They were real kind.
They didn't have a formal education, but they had good common sense.
And I think the more education you get, the more you appreciate people with common sense.
They were extremely good this way.
I was able to get my own interpreter, and it was rather unique.
I don't drink at all.
And when I went into the officer's club, I always had Cokes.
And a sister of the bartender in there, her name was Soon, and she was a 16-year-old girl.
And she learned to speak English from being in the officer's club there.
And a little later, I picked her up at 25 cents an hour to work in the supply department.
And since she was able to speak Vietnamese and English, I soon started taking her on my trips around Vietnam because she was my interpreter there.
And I had my own jeep, and being a senior supply corps officer, I was responsible for paying all the people in the three-quarter area of Vietnam.
So I did get out into the communities.
And I particularly noticed in each one of the communities that the new areas were all schools.
And the new buildings were schools.
The Vietnamese were finally educating the Buddhists.
When the French was there, the French only educated the Catholics.
And the Catholics make up about 10% of Vietnam, the Buddhists about 90%.
So as a result, with these new schools and with Vietnamese teachers, the people finally felt they were now getting something from the government.
And they were supporting the government in Saigon because now their children were getting an education where they didn't have that opportunity.
Before you came to Vietnam, how much did you know about their educational origins?
Were you trained or did you have any education?
No, I was supposed to go to a SEER school, a survival school, prior to that, prior to going over there.
But they cut that short because of Lieutenant Prince and some of the other people.
But as far as knowledge of Vietnam, prior to that, I had very little knowledge.
Do you have your opinion on the U.S. strategy?
Well, I think it was strictly political.
Had we wanted to win it, we could have very easily won it.
Politics was such a heavy factor in it that we weren't allowed to do what we wanted, and the Vietnamese weren't allowed to do what they wanted.
Now, to give you an example, I was very close with one of the Vietnamese colonels there.
And he said that he would like to see the Americans go primarily so that they could walk above the 17th parallel, give the North Vietnamese a dose of their own medicine.
Because the North Vietnamese were allowed to come down and sabotage and snipe in South Vietnam, but the Americans didn't allow the South Vietnamese to go up north and do the same thing.
The Vietnamese would have preferred that the Americans leave because all the Vietnamese girls were changing their habits.
They were becoming Americanized.
And they were running around with American men.
And they wanted their girls back to the Vietnamese men.
And the reason they were with American men is because the American men had the money.
And actually, the girls wanted the entertainment that was associated with the money that the Americans could provide them with.
How did you feel about the conventional war method versus the guerrilla war method?
Did you feel that we had, we were conventional, had conventional lines and went into a guerrilla warfare type of situation?
Well, we weren't really in a guerrilla warfare there.
They were.
Now, we could have been very successful in the guerrilla war against the North Vietnamese had we allowed the Vietnamese to go north.
And I might add, even when we bombed in North Vietnam, we could only hit certain targets.
I was with a Navy pilot that turned in his wings after 92 missions, and he says, I refuse to go anymore because we're not allowed to hit the targets we see down there.
He says, we can only hit the bridges.
And what happens is that...
They know exactly where we're coming.
They know exactly what our targets are, and they just lay up all kind of flak to the planes coming in.
Also, the Vietnamese would put all of their convoys in residential areas.
They stored all of their oil around the schools or in the churches.
I oil around the schools.

They put their anti-aircraft guns around the churches so that if we did knock them out, we'd either be hitting their schools or we'd be hitting their churches, which is the propaganda-type war that they're using against us.
Did you have any actual training or experiences in combat?
Oh, not really.
The first evening that I got into Cam Ranh Bay, they shot a few mortars over at us.
What time of the day was most active for you?
Well, being a Supply Corps officer, we had normal hours primarily.
We, of course, had our perimeter watches, and we had to do these entries and so on, and watched our perimeter.
But at Cameron Bay, we were particularly fortunate in that the mainland
between our base and Vietnam itself was patrolled by the South Koreans.
And the South Koreans were very dedicated to the task they were doing, and the Vietnamese didn't want to tangle with them.
They would rather come up against the Americans because the Americans would ask questions and usually not shoot, or the Koreans would usually shoot first if someone got into their area.
Comment on the quality of Arvin, South Vietnamese, and the enemy as fighters?
Yes, I think they were decent fighters.
This is contrary to the news media that we constantly heard.
I was with a Navy captain that was on the base where I was.
He was also in the Korean War.
And at the time I was there, which was 1970, 69 and 70, he said that the Vietnamese were far ahead of where the Koreans were at the same time.
So that he felt, as far as pacification was concerned, that the Vietnamese were far ahead of the Koreans and were making more progress, and had made progress quicker in 1970.
Do you have your views on Selective Service?
I would be in favor of Selective Service.
Mainly because I think our young people need to know what goes on in other countries.
I think that even if it's a six month tour, I think it would be wise to do this.
I think the conception
of the military is far different than what it actually is.
Prior to going into the military, I always thought someone who made a career out of the military was a person who couldn't get a job elsewhere.
That was the way I felt about it.
And, of course, once I got in, I liked the challenges and learned about the travel and the competition with my peer groups as being the same age as I am.
Okay, your views on the National Guard?
I don't have contact with the National Guard.
I don't think I'm given any intelligence.
Am I correct in saying that the National Guard did not play any part in Vietnam?
I didn't have any contact with them.
Who did you receive your orders from, or where did they originate?
My boss was in Saigon, Captain Hine, and he handled the funding for the base.
So that was about my immediate superior.
Now, he was a commanding officer of the base, also in the workforce, but as far as funding and so forth, he was not in Saigon.
What was your opinion about careerism?
in the military during Vietnam and did it since?
I was a career Navy man.
And like I said, I volunteered.
I was a lieutenant commander when I went over and made commander shortly after I went back.
I was already career.
I believed in what we were doing.
I still believe in what we were doing over there.
I think the U.S. Congress did the Vietnamese people a terrible injustice.
I think our news media was terribly slanted that portrayed a situation that was totally out of context.
When I first come back and I would hear the newscasters talking about areas that I've been in, I'd just jump out of my chair.
They were lying.
And then how our news media got this information or how it was posted, I really don't know.
But it was a terrible injustice to me and these people and the contacts that I had with them.
What about the, like, when they switched...
people in command so often.
In Vietnam?
Yeah, they rotated them every year.
Well, you could go back the second time.
You could go back again.
When you're away from your family a year, this can be detrimental to home life.
I don't know that I would want to send our men over there longer than a year at a time and still be married because that's a terribly long time for children to be without a father and so on.
Okay.
Could you comment on problems in Vietnam such as drugs?
The drugs were there.
I never had any problem in my department.
I handled quarters myself, and I was very emphatic that anyone in my department that was involved in drugs, that I wanted other members of my department to straighten them out.
And I told them I didn't want them to come to me with it, I wanted them to get it corrected because they were out in the perimeters protecting us when we were sleeping,
And many of them had been involved in drugs, and we couldn't sleep at night.
And I expected each of my people to straighten out anyone that would get involved in drugs.
And as a result, and the whole time I was there, I didn't have one single drug problem in my life.
OK. How about you?
No, we all took our pills while we were over there, took the malaria.
I remember one time the medical doctor came by my room and he says, why don't you take your salt tablets?
And I said, well, how do you know, doc?
And he said, well, look at your mouth.
And I had cold blisters on my mouth.
It was hot over there, very humid, and we perspired a lot.
So as a result, we had to take salt taverns and lack of salt when I would get cold sores.
That was the only effect that I ever had.
We took our malaria pills off.
We never had any trouble on our base with that.
Did you respect your leaders?
Oh, absolutely.
We had good people.
Not only this, I had the best men in Vietnam that I've had in the areas that I've worked in, the department I've run.
Mainly because they would send me a lot of college graduates in enlisted ranks.
And I just got excellent people.
Plus,

In the supply department, there's a lot of Filipinos that work in that area, and they were close to home, and they would have a chance about every two months to get a flight to the Philippines for a week.
So as a result, I had top notch Philippine enlisted men that ran the messes for me, that is the officer's clubs, the enlisted messes, the barber shop, also the retail store.
And I even had some in my regular supply department operations so that I just had top-notch people.
So I didn't find, I found that I had the best people over there.
And my department was run the best that I had run at any time in my career.
My Kardex system, which is what we use over there, said in my warehouse there was going to be three in a certain location.
I had three in a certain location.
I also had Vietnamese employees that worked with us, but they were real fine people and did an excellent job.
And the Russians are running over there now.
They got that base, and they got a fine running operation.
Do you feel you were justified in going over there in the first place, and why?
Well, I think that will probably be debated over the years.
I supported my government in doing this.
I felt they had a bigger picture than what I had of it.
And the communists were trying to take over that country by force.
And the Vietnamese people did not want the communists there.
We had set up the road system so that each of the handlers, they had reasonably good roads built by the U.S. military.
We set up the communication system from telephones to television where they were getting word out of Saigon as to what was happening from time to time.
Everything was set up in a communication manner
Initially, there was a big language barrier, but there were enough Lebanese that also spoke English by the time I was there that communications even verbally were excellent.
No, I thought they cooperated real well.
I didn't see a problem with this.
The Koreans were probably the best fighters over there, though.
Do you feel that the South Vietnamese
had a real desire to fight.
Yes, they did.
And they did because they wanted self-determination.
They wanted to be, they saw their government getting their kids an education.
And then

Even in the Delta, in the Mekong Delta, by the time I was there, it was in that period, 69 to 70, they were producing enough rice in the Delta, it was pacified enough that they could even export rice.
So they were getting their system back in order.
And I still am angry at the U.S. Congress and what they did to these people.
Do you think we could have won the war?
Absolutely.
By continuing to, when we pulled our troops out, just providing them with military supplies, there's no question in my mind that we would have won.
The stampede came out of the central part up in the last, which is a college area.
The stampede started up in that area.
as a result of the U.S. Congress cutting off aid, total aid to Vietnam.

Not only had the U.S. Congress and the President, President Nixon at the time, they said he'd take all the people out, but he promised them to give them military aid so that they could continue to fight for their own self-determination.
But then, after the bulk of our people were taken out, the U.S. Congress cut off the money.
As far as aid or supplies, when they did this, this caused the panic, and that panic just overran.
It was taken over by panic more than anything else.
And it was totally unnecessary, unjustified, and a black date, as far as I'm concerned, in American history.
So if you could put the blank on something.
It was Congress.
No doubt about it.
U.S. Congress and the liberal news media.
What was it like when you came home?
How did people react to you when you told them you wanted to come home?
Well, I never had a problem.
I read about people looking down on you in Vietnam.
I had a sister-in-law that my mother threw out of her house because she was having a fit that I was going to Vietnam.
And that's probably as close as anyone would be making any comments.
My feeling coming back, I didn't see anything adverse.
I wasn't looking for anything, any hero's welcome or anything like that.
I was doing my job as far as I was concerned.
I was doing what I felt was right for my country, and I still feel that.
So your views haven't changed since the war?
No, I'm not.

In fact, it angers me more that I see the way the U.S. Congress got away with doing that, and the news media support him, and even Walter Cronkite is coming out with his CBS capsule reports on Vietnam still supporting the lies that were perpetrated on American people at that time.
And it's wrong.
Did you have a question while you were in Portland?
No.
I volunteered and they're fine people.
I wish I could have helped them more.
To give you an example, one time I was downtown in my Jeep and since I was a lieutenant commander at the time, that's equivalent to a major.
And some young fellow was yelling at me.
He says, Major, Major.
He says, come here.
He says, my parents work for you.
See, I didn't know that.
And he says, come.
He says, I want you to see my home.
So I got out of my Jeep and I went over to his home.
And it was an area, oh, I would say maybe 12 feet square.
This is where the home where
There were the mother and three children.
And there was bare walls and the walls were about 12 inches off from the ground so that they had ventilation into the house.
And they had sheets of plywood leaning up against the wall that they laid on the floor with what they slept on at night.
And on the one wall was a crucifix.
They were a Catholic family.
But they had a black lacquer painting
that they had brought from North Vietnam.
They had been Catholic refugees from North Vietnam.
And he told me that the reason he could speak English, he was going to the University of the Latin, and he was studying to be a priest.
When I got back to my quarters, I went over to the Catholic chaplain and I told him about this boy and I said, surely there ought to be some Catholic charities.
And because his dad was making 50 cents an hour working for me as a carpenter.
I said, surely there ought to be a Catholic charity that could pick up this boy's education so that the family making such a meager wage wouldn't have to be going through all these costs.
So I took the Catholic chaplain over to the family, and sure enough, the Catholic charity did pick up his costs up until the time that I left the economy.
Whenever I left Vietnam, on my desk, the day I left, was this particular picture.
And this, it was the only thing they had.
And on it was a note.
It says that Commander, no, Major, it says, Major, no matter where you are, there will always be someone in Vietnam to watch you.
In general, tell me how the American soldiers felt about Vietnam all through the war up until the fallout.
Well, one of the difficulties were that a lot of them were draftees that went over there.
So, being draftees and maybe not being career type persons
Their attitudes were a lot different for serving in the military, let alone going to Vietnam where the press was certainly not based in the government continuum.
So there were a lot of boys that were over there that didn't want to be there, and fighting an unpopular war at home.
There was a lot of resentment.
We lost, particularly in the Navy and Marines, we lost a lot of young officers who were being dragged.
By that I mean that they were shot in the back by their own men or they were injured.
So we lost some good officers this way.
because of the caliber of people that particularly Marines and the Army say over there.
For one, the Marines should have never been involved.
That's the Army's job, not the Marines.
And they pulled the Marines in there.
And this hurt the Marine Corps for many years because of these draftees that got in there at this one o'clock in the morning or where they really wanted to be.
So the attitude of the Navy
was entirely different.
We didn't draft people to put them in Vietnam.
I had good men.
My men were solid.
They were good citizens.
They re-upped.
What I mean is they decided they wanted to stay there and continue their two-year tour or stay there longer.

Because every six months over there, if they would stay or request staying, they would get a 30-day rotation period where they would go to Hong Kong or to Singapore or the Philippines or Tokyo and so on for 30 days.
Is that for everyone?
Yes, for the enlisted personnel.
So every six months they would be given this.
So this was pretty nice, plus they were able to save everything that was made.
They were making all the money.
And they were making extra money because they were using it for something.
Why did we pull out ?
Of course, because of the politics at home, President Nixon said that he
or phase the people out, which he did.
And I think it was proper.
I think it was done.
I think the pacification had been completed.
I think it was time for the Vietnamese to go ahead and start making their own decisions and get the Americans out of that because I think they were trained well enough and they can handle it.
I think it was proper.
What was wrong was when Congress cut off the money.
The Vietnamese could have handled it.
They would have handled it.
And I think it's unforgivable if the U.S. Congress didn't do that.
What was your view on Antifa?
Do they have every right to do it?
I feel I was over there for the right
for those people to do that.
I did not agree with them as far as their protest is concerned, but I will continue to fight for their right to protest.
I think that this is important.
Any time I'm ever angry at my government and want to protest, I want to be able to do it.
Well, you see,
What was happening, when I come back, I wanted to get out and speak.
I wanted to do it.
And I was told very emphatically my job was to carry out foreign policy, not to make it.
When you're in the military, you carry out what the politicians, the mistakes the politicians make.
You go over there and leave for their mistakes.
Yeah, you might guess that I vote politicians in pretty low speed.
Because whenever they, when they're not successful, then they'll use the military to do their dirty work.
But, yeah, I will die for my country.
I've always said that.
I believe in the United States.
I love my country.
But I'll also fight for the right for those people to demonstrate against me when I'm wrong, or whenever they think that I'm wrong.
I think this is the great thing about a democracy, and I think everyone should have the right to demonstrate, and if the government makes a mistake, then they should have to face the gravity of it.
Oh yeah, I don't, I won't think about it.
It makes me very angry.
What you do is that you have to think positive thoughts.
And that's what I do.
So, no, I don't think positive thoughts.
I refuse to think positive thoughts.
Okay.
And this last question.
If you had a message to the college students today, try and clear up some misconceptions about Vietnam, what would it be?
Hmm.
I would suppose that I realize that the news media is involved in headlines, sensationalism, trying to get people to buy their publication.
And not necessarily are they always interesting to me.
And you're going to have to go beyond.
You really need to talk to the people to find out if the truth really is there.
Many times, the truth is bland, and it doesn't get published.
Or if it is, it gets on the fifth or sixth page after the sensationalists and the Republicans.
So I would think for young people today is that,
be very cautious with the freedom of the press.
It's something we have to fight to protect.
But also, with that freedom, they can do a lot of things that just aren't natural.
I appreciate that.
